Description: Mould-made scarab in glazed composition; markings on back are skewed, with miniature clypeus, single line for prothorax, elytra marked with double suture and distinct humeral callosities represented as winglets; profile of back is flattened and legs simplistically represented; underside bearing a hieroglyphic inscription arranged vertically, giving the name of Amun-Ra with three redundant vertical strokes (usual mark of the plural in Ancient Egyptian); inscription possibly stamped, encircled by groove near edge; longitudinally pierced; glaze well preserved, pale yellow in colour; core dirty yellow.
Curator's comments: The faience object was analysed by proton induced X-ray emission spectrometry (PIXE) under a 3 MeV energy proton beam for characterisation of the elemental chemical composition (major, minor and trace elements), in March 2014, by the Centre de Recherche et de Restauration des Musées de France (C2RMF). Variants of the name of Amun-Ra are a common theme on scarabs and scaraboids produced at the 'Scarab Factory' (Petrie 1886, pl. 37, 89-93; Gardner 1888, pl. 18, no. 25; on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming). This scarab was discovered in the 'Scarab Factory' itself with another similar scarab (signalled on the drawing Petrie 1886, pl. 37, 91), likely Paris, Louvre Museum E8056 bis.11. These scarabs belong to the type XXVIII B in Gorton 1996, which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 93, 101-107). Gardner, E. A. 1888, Naukratis. Part II (Sixth Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Gorton, A. F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W. M. F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, 'Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site', in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming,Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th –17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 91) (similar type)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OC.089) (phase 3)
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 2016, 19 May-27 Nov, BM exhibition Sunken Treasures
